description: From French régaler (“to entertain, feast”), from Old French regale, rigale, from gale (“merriment”), probably of Germanic origin (see Old French galer). Influenced by Old French se rigoler (“amuse oneself, rejoice”), of unknown origin. Compare Middle High German begalen (“to charm; enchant”), English gale (“to sing; charm”). Compare also English gala.

entries.meaning: (archaic) a choice article of food or drink.

verbs.description: regale (third-person singular simple present regales, present participle regaling, simple past and past participle regaled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide hospitality for (someone); to supply with abundant food and drink. [from 17th c.]
(obsolete, intransitive) To feast (on, with something). [17th–19th c.]
examples: she hardly lets a Week pass without making the Lady Abbess and her Nuns a Visit, to regale with a Cup of burnt Brandy.

entries.meaning: (figurative, transitive) To entertain with something that delights; to gratify; to refresh.
examples: to regale the taste, the eye, or the ear
